prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Throughout this proposal, we aim to maximize the spectral window around each line in order to ensure the detection of the outflow-related line wings and of the continuum. The diffuse biconical outflow has so far been detected within a velocity range of 500 km/s, but at the north lobe, velocities from -1000 km/s to 1000 km/s have been found in the SINFONI data.
Our final spectral resolution, common for all lines, will be 70km/s, which is identical to the width of the SINFONI pixels around the H2 (1-0) S(1) line. This resolution allows structures with velocity difference of 200km/s to be separated, and it suits well the study of the diffuse outflow, which clearly progresses from the nucleus to the point P2 of Fig. 1 from 0 to 450 km/s (Dasyra et al. 2015). The diffuse outflow peaks ~500 km/s away from the disk average circular velocity at that point. A final resolution of 70 km/s also suits well the study of the north/south lobe outflow velocity range from -1000 to -600 km/s and 600 to 1000 km/s (i.e., outside ordered motions).
Through this proposal, we use spectral averaging to bin the data of spectral line windows to 5(+-2) km/s channels. This choice enables us to lower the data rate, and still be able to detect individual clouds in absorption, should the continuum levels permit this.

The separation between several starting points of the outflow (e.g., P2, P3, P4 in Fig. 1) is about 100 pc. By selecting a resolution of 0.4", we ensure that the spatial points will be resolved, without rendering the detection of the diffuse flux hard to achieve. For band 3 data, this corresponds to the configuration C36-6.
The maximum angular scale of the source covers the full extent of the diffuse outflow, and the outflow components at the north lobe, south lobe, and along the jet trail that connects these lobes (Fig 1,2). (Some of the host galaxy ambient emission outside the central kpc may be missed, but this is of no importance for our analysis.)

We aim at the detection of the diffuse biconical H2 outflow. Notably, this is the outflow component with the lowest surface brightness, so its detection ensures the outflow detection in all other regions (e.g., north lobe, south lobe).
Our computation for its CO(1-0) flux density/beam is as follows. In the mm range, the total outflow emission (spatially integrated within 7 kpc of the nucleus) has been detected in CO(2-1) SEST data with a peak flux density of 80 mJy (Morganti et al. 2013). To be conservative, we assume that the CO spectral line energy distribution is similar to that of the Milky Way (toward the Galactic Center). Then, S_CO(2-1)/S_CO(1-0) ~ 2 (Fixsen 1999), and S_CO(1-0)=40 mJy.
To obtain the spatial distribution of the outflow flux density, we use the SINFONI H2 (1-0) S(1) data presented in Dasyra et al. (2015). There, the diffuse biconical outflow accounts for 15% of the total outflow emission. (Likewise, the north lobe contributes 45%, and the south lobe and the nucleus 20% of the emission). Therefore, S_CO(1-0)[diffuse outflow]= 40*0.15=6 mJy. The diffuse outflow extends to a region exceeding 4"x2", but 60% of its flux comes from an elongated region south of the jet trail that is comprised within 3 beams of 0.4". We thus ascribe a flux of 6 mJy*0.6/3.=1.2 mJy to the diffuse outflow peak flux density per beam. We request a sensitivity of 0.4 mJy that allows for a 3 sigma detection of the line peak.
With this sensitivity, the outflow component at the north lobe will be detectable at 10 sigma levels.
Integrated over the whole galaxy, the dust emission as predicted from the SED is 300 mJy. If it is distributed like the gas in the ALMA cycle 2 data (~a radius 8"), and our beam radius is 0.2", then the continuum/beam will be 0.2mJy.

The chosen spectral resolution leads to a spectral window of ~1600 km/s.
For both CO(3-2) and HCO+(4-3), we use two windows (one from -1300km/s to 300km/s and another from -300km/s to 1300km/s) to cover both line wings up to 1300 km/s. That helps us cover the velocity range of the molecular gas in the SINFONI data and sample the immediately nearby continuum. This setup offers a couple of additional advantages: we do not split the main disk emission in two datacubes, and we can test that the continuum left and right of each line is well anchored. This consistency test is key for the detection of outflow-related wings.
The data binning justification is as in Science Goal 1.
The angular resolution has to be the same as in CO(1-0), doable in configuration C36-3.

Starting again from the peak CO(2-1) flux density in the entire (spatially integrated) outflow, 80 mJy, and using the Milky Way S_CO(3-2)/S_CO(2-1) ratio, 1.2, we find that the outflow will in total have a peak flux density of 96 mJy. Assuming, again that 15% of the outflow emission comes from the diffuse biconical component, and that 60% of the emission in this component comes from a area equal to 3 beams, we find that the CO(3-2) peak flux density per beam will be 2.9 mJy.
In addition to the CO(3-2) data, HCO+(4-3) can be simultaneously obtained in the second sideband. To estimate the HCO+(4-3) flux density, we use the CO(4-3) flux density (see Science Goal 3) and a CO(4-3)/HCO+(4-3) ratio of 4, which is equal to the CO(1-0)/HCO+(1-0) ratio in the outflow of Mrk 231 (Feruglio et al. 2010; Aalto et al.2011). We are thus implicitely assuming a HCO+(4-3)/HCO+(1-0) of ~3 (like that of the CO, which is moderate; see Papadopoulos et al. 2007 and Imanishi et al. 2010 for a comparison).
To aim for a 3-sigma detection of the HCO+(4-3) in the diffuse outflow, we thus request a sensitivy of 0.3 mJy. CO(3-2) will then be detected in the diffuse outflow with a S/N of 10.
From the dust SED, the predicted continuum at the reference frequency is 700mJy. Assuming a beam scaling factor of (0.2"/8")^2, like before, we get a continuum/beam of 0.4mJy.

Two spectral windows side-by-side fill the sideband and cover the range that we are interested in (-1200<V<1200 kms). A third spectral window centered at the line center is used so that the regular disk emission is not split in two cubes and so that the continuum left and right of the line is well anchored.
The selected parameters (and their justification) are as in Science Goal 1. The needed configuration will be C36-2.

Starting once more from a total CO(2-1) peak flux density in the outflow of 80 mJy, using the Milky Way S_CO(4-3)/S_CO(2-1) flux ratio, 1.4, and the previously assumed diffuse outflow spatial distribution (see Science Goal 1), we find a CO(4-3) peak flux density/beam of 3.3 mJy. We again aim at a 3 sigma detection per beam.
From the dust SED, the predicted continuum is at 1100mJy. Assuming as before a beam scaling factor of (0.2"/8")^2, then we get a continuum/beam of 0.7mJy.
The selected parameters (and their justification) are as in Science Goal 1.
The selected parameters (and their justification) are as in Science Goal 1.

To scale the fluxes of HCN(1-0), HNC(1-0), and HCO+(1-0) with respect to that of CO(1-0), we use the measured ratios in the outflow of Mrk231 (Feruglio et al. 2010, Aalto et al. 2011). These are in the range 3-5 for all three lines. We thus take the predicted CO(1-0) peak flux density/beam and divide it by 4. Although weaker, the lines can be observed at the south lobe (1.8mJy) and at the north lobe (4.5mJy). Even though the detection in the diffuse biconical outflow in this case remains to be tested, even a limit on it will provide useful information on the HCO+ excitation (e.g., if it is nearly thermalized or not).
The sensitivity threshold of 300mJy that we set is identical to that for the HCO+(4-3) line. It enables us to detect the south lobe in 3 sigma/beam, even if half its flux turns out to be unresolved at 0.4" or even if the HCO+ / HCN / HNC lines turn out to be one order of magnitude fainter than the corresponding CO line.
The flux of the south lobe -not that of the diffuse outflow- has been assigned to the "peak line flux/beam" in this case.
A continuum identical with that of CO(1-0) has been assumed.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Gas compression is a requirement for jet-induced star formation. We aim to test whether the passage of a radio jet leads to the compression of the molecular gas it encounters in an ideal target: the nearby elliptical IC5063, in which a jet propagates through a disk. Using ultra-deep SINFONI observations, we demonstrated that the jet unambiguously accelerates atomic & molecular gas along and perpendicularly to its trail. The gas velocities exceed ordered motions by 600-1200 km/s near four different bending points of the jet. The entrained/scattered gas extends far, sweeping the galaxy's inner square kpc. Having a map of the outflowing molecular gas at high temperatures from SINFONI, we now aim to create a map of the outflowing molecular gas at high densities from ALMA, in order to identify regions of high pressure. In these regions, we will investigate whether the ISM is more or less prone to star formation. We request CO(1-0),(3-2), and (4-3) observations to run CO excitation models and obtain a density map. To directly probe the high-density regime and constrain the models, we request HCN, HNC, HCO+(1-0) and HCO+(4-3) observations.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: National and Kapodistrian University of Athens
